history.content:
The 106 labs are very useful for learning ROS, the main framework people in robotics use, and also working with robots hands-on. The final project is also very useful for getting research/jobs in robotics if you do a good job. By rigor, yes this class isn't particularly proof and theory heavy, since many of the concepts you learn are more of applied bag of tools in kinematics, vision, grasping, and control that are more "plug in chug" into this formula. However, unless you already have experience with working with Sawyer/Baxter robots (in research or internships), the hands-on and labs side of 106 can give you very good experience with working with actual robots in the real world. If you want more theory in kinematics, control and ai/ml and vision, physics courses, 120, 128, 126, 127, 189, 194-26/280 would be great to couple with 106.

106A/B TA here. 106A isn't very rigorous, but 106B is much more so. I still think it's very useful though and as the above poster said, it's very applicable. If you're looking at the hardware/control side of robotics, I'd recommend also looking at some classes in ME. The CS department doesn't do the best job at teaching system modeling, and there are a lot of good dynamics/robotics courses in MechE. I recommend 128 pretty highly, but you need to go to grad school before you learn applicable controls beyond PID (231A is a good one). Some people have recommended 192 to me, but it's a lot closer to the PCB than you'll get in a lot of robotics situations, and it's definitely not rigorous.

I keep hearing 106 is not very rigorous, (Maybe because it's cross listed with BIOE?) but I am very interested in robotics and in particular manufacturing, or robotic assembly lines.

Any suggestions?
history.subject: EECS C128 and EECS 192, or EECS C106A & B?
